contents.title: Architecture
contents.description: Understand how parsers, plugins, storage, and dashboards fit together.

children.value: BundleWatch is a pnpm monorepo with small, composable packages. Everything shares the same
, so plugins and the CLI can swap data freely.

props.code:
@milencode/bundlewatch-core (types + collectors + comparison + git storage)
        ‚Üì
        ‚îú‚îÄ @milencode/bundlewatch-parsers    # ingest bundler outputs
        ‚îú‚îÄ @milencode/bundlewatch-vite-plugin
        ‚îú‚îÄ @milencode/bundlewatch-webpack-plugin
        ‚îú‚îÄ @milencode/bundlewatch-next-plugin
        ‚îú‚îÄ @milencode/bundlewatch-cli
        ‚îî‚îÄ @milencode/bundlewatch-dashboard (HTML output helpers)

@milencode/bundlewatch-core (types + collectors + comparison + git storage)
        ‚Üì

convert native bundler stats (Webpack stats, Vite/Rollup bundles) to
to collect metrics (after a build, after
, etc.) and how to persist them.

Originally every plugin walked the output directory, recompressed assets, and guesstimated dependency graphs. The parser packages now tap into the bundler‚Äôs own metadata so the work happens in-memory:
Read every file ‚Üí gzip ‚Üí brotli ‚Üí stitch metrics
Consume stats/bundle JSON in memory ‚Üí map to metrics
. The Vite plugin still relies on
writes metrics to an orphan branch (default
). Each branch gets its own folder:
During CI the plugin/CLI saves the current metrics and optionally compares against another branch before logging a report or failing budgets.
builds a treemap from either detailed dependency metrics or the bundle list.
Webpack plugin ships an ‚Äúenhanced dashboard‚Äù (modules, dependencies, source-file stats) because the parser returns all that info.
Vite/Next/CLI still render a simpler treemap until they switch to parser-derived data.
‚Äì let these consume parser outputs or accept pre-generated stats.
‚Äì keep this site in sync with code changes by updating Markdown alongside Pull Requests.

contents.title: CLI
contents.description: Analyze any build output with the BundleWatch CLI.

children.value: Use the CLI when you don‚Äôt want to wire a plugin or when you‚Äôre analyzing arbitrary build output.
‚Äì compare against a branch on the data repo.
). If warnings are emitted, the process exits with code
so CI can fail the job.
Load two snapshots from Git storage and print a diff.
Generate badge/markdown output without running a fresh analysis.
Track CLI issues in the monorepo to see what‚Äôs coming up next.

contents.title: Deployment
contents.description: Ship the docs to Cloudflare Workers (Pages has been sunset).

children.value: Cloudflare Pages is deprecated (Nov 2025), so we deploy the statically generated docs via a Worker.
Cloudflare Workers now handle static assets directly‚Äîno R2 bucket required. The repository already includes a Worker project under
The handler uses the new Assets binding to serve files and fall back to
Set up a custom domain via Cloudflare Workers routes.
Provide two repository secrets so the job can authenticate with Cloudflare:
‚Äì token with ‚ÄúWorkers Scripts:Edit‚Äù + ‚ÄúWorkers KV Storage:Edit‚Äù (assets) permissions.
. Vercel Edge Functions can also serve the static assets, but Cloudflare Workers keeps everything in one ecosystem.

contents.title: Framework Recipes
contents.description: Apply the Vite plugin to Nuxt, SvelteKit, SolidStart, and other frameworks.

children.value: Many modern frameworks sit on top of Vite or Webpack. Rather than duplicating entire guides, this page shows the small glue code needed to wire BundleWatch into each one. Every snippet below assumes you‚Äôve already installed the appropriate plugin:

props.code:
pnpm add -D @milencode/bundlewatch-vite-plugin   # Vite-based frameworks
pnpm add -D @milencode/bundlewatch-webpack-plugin # Webpack-based frameworks

children.value: pages first‚Äîthese instructions just adapt them to framework‚Äëspecific entry points.
, capturing both SPA and SSG output.
; BundleWatch still gets accurate sizes because the Vite hook receives in-memory chunks before Nitro emits files.
if you also maintain the docs workspace inside the same repo.
. Works with any adapter (Node, Cloudflare, etc.) because BundleWatch executes during the Vite build phase.
; BundleWatch logs the analyzed files in the console so you can confirm what‚Äôs tracked.
When using adapters that rebuild during prerender (
SolidStart projects export a normal Vite config. Just append the plugin to the array.
) and edge adapters because BundleWatch runs during the build step, not the runtime.
. This captures both client and server bundles generated by Astro integrations.
; both show up in the BundleWatch treemap.
Turn off dashboard generation locally if you only need console output:
Qwik apps also rely on Vite. Drop BundleWatch into the config used by
Because Qwik ships lots of tiny chunks, enabling the parser-based Vite plugin (work in progress) will give more precise dependency graphs in the dashboard.
Remix can be configured to build with Webpack or Vite depending on the adapter. Use the matching BundleWatch plugin:
since Remix simply forwards to a Vite config.
Next already has a dedicated guide because it ships extra features (per-route analysis, budgets). See
for details. Use the same page for Remix-on-Next or custom Webpack wrappers that piggyback on Next‚Äôs build pipeline.

If a framework exposes Vite or Webpack config, you can drop the relevant BundleWatch plugin in place. When you discover framework-specific quirks (custom output paths, CI flags, etc.), open a PR to add another section here so future users have a reference.***

contents.title: Getting Started
contents.description: Install the docs workspace and connect BundleWatch to your builds.

children.value: This guide walks you through spinning up the docs workspace plus integrating BundleWatch into a project.
The docs live inside the main pnpm workspace, so run the standard install from the repo root:
This installs Nuxt + @nuxt/content alongside the existing packages. Use Node 20.10+ (we run on Node 24 in CI).
Content changes hot-reload instantly thanks to Nuxt Content.
Add BundleWatch to a Vite app
directory, prints a console report, and writes metrics to the Git storage branch.
The docs ship as a statically generated site:
ready to deploy to GitHub Pages or any static host.

links.text: Add BundleWatch to a Vite app

contents.title: Welcome
contents.description: Understand what BundleWatch solves and how the docs are organized.

children.value: BundleWatch tracks your bundle sizes over time, compares builds, and publishes visual dashboards directly inside your repository. These docs explain how the system fits together, how to plug it into different bundlers, and how to work with the Git-backed storage layer.
covers installing the CLI or framework plugins and wiring BundleWatch into CI/CD.
explains how metrics are written to an orphan branch so you can diff trends without provisioning a database.
Deep-dives for the Vite, Webpack, and Next.js plugins will land soon. Each section maps to the packages that live in this monorepo (
The README grew unwieldy while the architecture evolved. A Nuxt Content site lets us:
Keep long-form explanations versioned with the rest of the repo.
Statically generate the entire site (SSG) so it can deploy anywhere (GitHub Pages, Netlify, Vercel, etc.).
at the repo root (this also installs the docs workspace).
Edit or create Markdown files in
. The sidebar automatically reflects frontmatter titles and descriptions.

contents.title: Next.js Plugin
contents.description: Add BundleWatch to Next.js builds with per-route metrics.

children.value: This wrapper hooks into Next.js‚Äô Webpack config to run BundleWatch after client builds complete. It currently reuses the core collector (like the CLI), but still provides per-route stats via
Wraps your exported config and injects a Webpack plugin that runs after the client bundle finishes.
Optionally prints a per-route table by reading
Budgets are checked per pattern. If a route exceeds
, a warning prints (and the build fails if

Once the Webpack plugin exposes more parser data, the Next wrapper will piggyback on it to provide module-level insights and enhanced dashboards automatically. Watch the ‚Äúnext-plugin parser parity‚Äù issue for status.
shows the simplest integration‚Äîonly the client build runs BundleWatch, and dashboards are stored under

contents.title: Git Storage
contents.description: How BundleWatch persists metrics in an orphan branch.

children.value: BundleWatch avoids external databases by storing metrics JSON files inside a dedicated Git branch (default:
). Each CI run writes the current metrics and updates
per branch. This keeps history auditable and makes comparisons trivial.
BundleWatch collects metrics after your build (plugins or CLI).
holds the most recent snapshot per branch for quick lookups.
CI pushes the orphan branch back to origin.

props.code:
permissions:
  contents: write

steps:
  - uses: actions/checkout@v4
    with:
      fetch-depth: 0
  - run: pnpm install
  - run: pnpm build

children.value: (default in CI) on the plugin or CLI call so metrics are persisted automatically.
Keep the docs aligned with the code by updating this section whenever the storage contract changes.

contents.title: Vite Plugin
contents.description: Wire BundleWatch into Vite or Rollup builds.

children.value: The current Vite plugin relies on the legacy filesystem collector (
hook. A parser-driven version is in progress; until then you still get Git storage, comparisons, and dashboards.
Framework-specific examples (Nuxt, SvelteKit, SolidStart, Astro) live in
for a complete setup with source maps, dashboard generation, and CI-ready defaults:
Loads metrics from Git storage and runs
and scans that directory after the build finishes. If you customise the output directory (e.g.,
) the plugin picks it up automatically.

props.code:
permissions:
  contents: write
steps:
  - uses: actions/checkout@v4
    with:
      fetch-depth: 0
  - uses: actions/setup-node@v4
    with:
      node-version: 24
  - uses: pnpm/action-setup@v2
    with:
      version: 9
  - run: pnpm install
  - run: pnpm build

children.value:
